title: Map Building without Localization by Dimensionality Reduction Techniques
segmentation: Target surgery I'm from University of Tokyo.
Today I will talk about the mobile robot map building by dimensionality reduction.
Here is the outline of my talk.
First, I will explain the background of this research and I will review some related works.
And describe the proposed framework and show some experiment results.
And 1st I like to explain the motivation of this work.

I am interested in the mobile robot map building because I believe that it is an essential capability for intelligent agents such as humans and robots and in the mobile robot research slam or simultaneous localization and mapping has been the mainstream for many years and it has been very successful both in the theory and practice.
And of course I myself like slam too, but I feel something is missing.
And I have questions like the mapping and localization, really inseparable and other motion and measurement models necessary in advance.
And how about the aspect of map building as a obstruction of the world?
So I'm wondering if there is another map building framework.
So the purpose of this work is to reconsider the robot map building from the viewpoint of dimensionality reduction.
And propose a alternative framework named localization free mapping by dimensionality reduction, or LF MDR.
And this framework does not require localization and does not require motion or measurement models.
And this framework is based on heuristics that is closely located.
Objects tend to share similar histories of being observed by a robot.
And now I'd like to sketch the map building program we consider here.

In this work, we focus on a feature based map or object based map in which map is represented by by the two dimensional coordinates of objects, and we assume that there exist motion and measurement models generating the data observation data, but.
They are not necessarily known in advance.
And now I'd like to remind you some related works and I should mention SLAM 1st and in the framework of SLAM.
The problem is to estimate the map and robot tragic trajectory from the measurement data.
Given the motion model and measurement model.
And the number of solutions have been developed, such as common filter with extended state and incremental maximum likelihood en route backwards particle filter.
And in any case motion and measurement models must be given and at mentions of map and lower positions are tightly coupled.
And our idea is to use dimensionality reduction for mapping, but this idea is not new itself.

For example, in the work of Bronze Q. Android, Probabilistic PCA was used to extract low dimensional geometric features from the range measurements and in the work of pills and keypass, PCA was used to obtain low level mappings between the robots and actions.
And the perceptions.
And another idea of using dimensionality reduction is to estimate the robot states from a sequence of high dimensional observation data.
And as far as I know.
Appearance manifolds by harm and action respecting embedding by bowling and with Islam by fairies are based on this idea.

And if we represent the observation data from time time 12 N as a matrix, this method treats the row vectors of the metrics as data points and they estimate the trajectory of their states from the observation data by dimensionality reduction.
So now let's move onto the proposed framework and 1st we have to make some assumptions.
First, all objects are uniquely identifiable, so we don't consider the data Association program here.
And Secondly, we assume that the measurement model can be decomposed to homogeneous sub models for individual objects like this and.

This decomposition means an observation about an object is roughly dependent only on its location given the map and the robots position, and the third assumption is that locations of at least three objects are known in advance, and we call them unk objects.
And we I have to say that the second assumption may look too restrictive.
But thanks to this.
Option.
We can imagine the mapping between object position and its history of observation.
And this mapping.
Implies.
Intuitively, if two objects are closely located specially, then their histories histories of the visions are also similar.
And this summarizes the procedure of building map based on this framework.
First, the robot explores the environment and obtain the observation history data.
And then break the observation data matrix into a set of column vectors and applier.
Apply your favorite dimensionality reduction method to the vectors and obtain a set of two dimensional vectors.
And perform the optimal often transformation with respect to the anchor objects and obtain the final estimates.
And.
Let's look at the features of this framework compared with SLAM.
First, they are both based on the state space model and assume that there there will be.

Well, there are some motion and measurement models behind the data, but our framework is different from SLAM in that it does not assume that motion and measurement models are known in advance and the map is directly estimated from the observation without robot without estimating the robots positions.
So we call this framework localization free mapping.
But I have to say that this framework has several advantages compared with SLAM.
For example, this framework is basically offline batch procedure and generally it requires a larger amount of data.
Because it does not use the models and also currently this framework assumes that there is no missing data in the observation.
And we can.
We can also compare our framework with other existing dimensionality reduction based approaches described before.
For example, compared with the work of Brunskill and Roy, we apply our.
We use the dimensionality reduction to estimate the global map while their work for their method used dimensional reduction to estimate the extract local geometrical features.
And compared with the works of humbling and fairies, we apply the dimensionality reduction to the column vectors of the observation data matrix and estimate the object positions while.
They they apply the dimensionality reduction to the row vectors to grow victors of the data metrics and estimate the robot positions.
So now I'd like to show you some simulation results and this time we apply this framework to two different situations.
The first experiment is visibility only mapping and the 2nd is bearing only mapping and in both cases we assume that there are 50 objects including four anchor objects.
And the robot exposure environment with random direction, no change and obstacle avoidance.
And we we evaluate the build Maps by mean position, error and mean orientation errors.
And this time we.
We used variety of dimensionality reduction techniques ranging from ordinary linear PCA to normal nonlinear methods such as Markov MD S kernel.
PCA is a map of every Laplacian, eigen, map, Hessian, LLE and semidefinite embedding.
And in the first experiment we applied this framework to the visibility only mapping.

And in the visibility only mapping the robot builds a map using only visibility information and here visibility stand for whether each object is visible or not from each load position and in this simulation we assume that we make assumption to generate the observation data.
Object is visible if it's horizontal.
Visual angle of known occluded part is larger than 5 degrees.

And in this case, the visibility observation data is represented as a binary matrix and its column vector or observation history vector is represented as a binary vector, and we normalize this binary vector by its Euclidean norm because.
Stu to compensate the variety of the frequencies of the.
Each are objects are how often, how often each object is observed.

And these figures show the examples of build Maps after 2000 observation steps and the Red lines red lines in these figures emphasized deviations from the two positions, so you can see that the linear PCA and kernel PCA perform very poorly.
On the other hand, other nonlinear.
Assault performs very well and successful in estimating the accurate positions of objects.
And this shows are harder.
Mean position errors, degrees as long as as the number of steps increases.
And this table summarizes the average final map errors, and in this case we can see that the semidefinite embedding performs best and followed by zone map and HLA E.

And in the second experiment we apply the framework to the bearing only mapping and bearing in the bearing only mapping the robot builds a map only with the bearing measurements or relative direction angles to the objects.
And this experiment was originally motivated by the recent popularity of bearing only some in the.
Field of mobile robot.
And.
But in our case, we assume that all objects are always visible, because as I said, currently this framework does not allow missing observation.
And in this case we used.
You need you need directional vectors of the bearing angle instead of the bearing angle itself, because because it avoids the problem of discontinuity between the Pi and minus π.
And this figures.
These figures show the.
Examples of Maps after 2000 observation steps.
And this time, our little surprisingly linear PCA performs much better than the previous case.
And actually, it seems that linear PCA performs better than the Laplacian eigen map.
And this table.
Summarizes.
Average final map errors.

And this time's Markov algorithm performs the best and followed by semidefinite embedding and isomap and surprisingly, linear PCA performs better than the elderly and Laplacian eigen map, and I'm not sure but.
I think that this might imply that the distribution of the observation histories approach is too linear as a number of observations increase.
So now I'd like to conclude my talk in this study.
We reconsidered the robot map building from the viewpoint of dimensionality reduction.
And we propose the new framework named LF MDR.
And in this framework, motion and measurement models are not required and it does not require estimate the.
It is not required to estimate the robot positions.
But however, generally it requires a large amount of data.
And we tested this framework on two types of sensor measurements and they're visibility, information and bearing angles.
And we compare the variety of dimensionality reduction methods on these experiments.
And we have a lot of future works, especially I like to relax the restrictions, especially.
I want to deal with the missing measurements and their Association program on this framework.
And also there are several interesting problems such as scalability and online algorithm, and much sense of Fusion.
OK, that's all.
